data.title: On soccer: After Euro flameout, what becomes of the Dutch?
data.meta_description: Will coach Bert van Marwijk hold on to his job?
data.text:
While the European Championship is the second-most prestigious tournament to win next to the World Cup, it’s first in terms of quality of competition. Even this year, with co-hosts Poland and Ukraine guaranteed a place in the field when they normally might not have earned it, just about every game has been highly competitive and fairly exciting.

That also explains how the Netherlands could enter the Euros ranked No. 4 in the world and, two weeks later, slink back home following three straight losses, the final one to Portugal, 2-1, Sunday.

Taking nothing away from Portugal, which finally played a game worthy of its talent after an embarrassing World Cup performance two years ago, nobody could have forseen the Dutch demise.

So we pose the question. What happens to the Dutch now?

Coach Bert van Marwijk selected a roster that was similar to the one he picked for the 2010 World Cup. That group propelled the Netherlands to the final, where it lost to Spain in overtime.

But that game also was a black mark on the country’s soccer history. Rather than match its free-flowing style of play against a similar Spanish attack, the Dutch instead resorted to a physical style of play, where they committed 28 fouls, were issued nine yellow cards and finished the game with 10 men.

Getting to the World Cup final was a tribute to van Marwijk, who skillfully massaged all the big egos into a team-first mentality.

This team was expected to continue that quest for the country’s first title since the 1988 Euros, and it seemed on track as the Dutch breezed through qualifying. Slotted into Group E, the Netherlands won their first nine games, losing their final game to Sweden, 3-2, after wrapping up a Euro berth.

More important, the Dutch racked up 37 goals in 10 games and seemed unstoppable.

But the team had questions coming into the Euros. Their defense had a few injuries and there were inexperienced players filling in. Even more worrysome, there was division in the team on who should start at striker, Robin van Persie or Klass-Jan Huntelaar?

Both had led their respective leagues in scoring, van Persie in England and Huntelaar in Germany. But in van Marwijk’s system, only one would start, and he chose van Persie.

That would have been fine if all went well, but when it didn’t, well, you saw the result. The griping started following an opening loss to Denmark, and when the Dutch lost to Germany in the second game the panic really set it. Sunday’s loss to Portugal, in which van Marwijk started both strikers in an effort to generate some much-needed offense, resulted in the Netherlands’ worst result since it failed to qualify for the 2002 World Cup.

The retooling, however, must begin now, especially with the team’s first World Cup qualifier in three months, and it will be interesting to see if van Marwijk will still be there moving forward. When a team is fractured, the message gets lost, and when players believe a coach screwed up, a fresh voice is usually needed.

But this is not a country devoid of talent. On the contrary, not many countries develop players as talented as the Netherlands. Among the key players in the squad, goalkeeper Maarten Stekelenburg and midfielder Rafael van der Vaart are 29, while Huntelaar, van Persie and midfielders Wesley Sneijder and Arjen Robben are all 28, so they should still be at the top of their game at the 2014 World Cup.

What will also help is that come September, the Netherlands won’t be under such duress to qualify, having been drawn in a relatively easy group with Andorra, Estonia, Hungary, Romania and Turkey.

Their their first game, however, is against the second-best team in the field, Turkey on Sept. 7. And if the long qualifying process begins with yet another loss, things could turn ugly pretty quickly.

Frank Giase: fgiase@starledger.com

ETC....

Egypt, which had been unbeaten in 13 games this year under Bob Bradley, was upset, 3-2, at home by the Central African Republic in the first leg of their African Cup of Nations qualifier. The second leg will be played June 30, with Egypt in danger of missing the tournament for the second successive time. ... The U.S. women's national team won the three-team Swedish Invitational, beating Sweden, 3-1, and Japan, 4-1. Abby Wambach and Alex Morgan scored three goals apiece and Tobin Heath netted the other. Sweden and Japan play their game Wednesday. ... Sporting Kansas City will play French champion Montpellier in a friendly July 24 in Kansas City. Four days later, Montpellier will play Lyon in the Trophee des Champions at Red Bull Arena. ... The Colorado Rapids re-signed defender Drew Moor to a multiyear contract. ... Real Salt Lake forward Alvaro Saborio scored three goals in Costa Rica's 4-0 victory over Guyana in a World Cup qualifier last week. ... The Seattle Sounders will be without forward David Estrada for eight to 12 weeks after he broke his left foot in training. ... San Jose Earthquakes goalkeeper Jon Busch was suspended for one game and fined an undisclosed amount for aggressively retrieving a ball during second-half stoppage time in a May 27 game at Sporting Kansas City. Busch will serve his suspension Wednesday night against Colorado. ... The Philadelphia Union fired coach Peter Nowak. Assistant John Hackworth took over on an interim basis and lost his first game Saturday night, 1-0, to D.C. United. ... Toronto FC players Miguel Aceval, Nick Soolsma and Luis Silva have been charged with public intoxication after police said they got in a fight outside a Houston nightclub and then argued with officers. ... The Vancouver Whitecaps' 1-0 victory over the Colorado Rapids Saturday night was their seventh of the season, surpassing their total from last year's expansion team that finished 6-10-18. ... Denmark forward Nicklas Bendtner, who revealed an unofficial sponsor's name on his underwear while celebrating a goal at the European Championship, paid the price. UEFA fined Bendtner $126,000 and suspended him for Denmark's opening World Cup qualifier against the Czech Republic Sept. 8. ... Damien Duff wore the captain's armband for Ireland in its 2-0 loss to Italy Monday in recognition of his 100th cap. ... Spain coach Vicente del Bosque signed a two-year contract extension through the 2014 World Cup. ... Doctors cleared defender Eric Abidal to travel to Kiev today to watch France's final Group D game against Sweden in the European Championship. Abidal, who plays for Barcelona, had a liver transplant two months ago. ... Barcelona coach Tito Vilanova agreed to a two-year contract that will keep him at the club until 2014. Spain's 4-0 win over Ireland at the Euros was Ireland's most lopsided loss in 41 years. Spain also completed an incredible 779 passes in the game. ... Greece captain Giorgos Karagounis tied his country's record for appearances with his 120th cap in Saturday's 1-0 win over Russia. Karagounis, who equalled the record set in 2007 by midfielder Theo Zagorakis, is suspended for Friday's quarterfinal against Germany after picking up two yellow cards in the three group games. ... Forward Lukas Podolski earned his 100th cap for Germany in Sunday's 2-1 victory over Denmark in a European Championship group game, making him the youngest player in German history to reach the milestone. ... England's 3-2 win over Sweden in the Euros last week was its first over the Swedes in a tournament game or qualifier in eight tries. ... Greece beat Russia, 1-0, in the Euros to advance out of Group A despite being outshot, 25-5. ... Still think Europe's money crisis doesn't affect big clubs? On Monday the Scottish Premier League released its schedule for the upcoming season and Rangers were omitted due to the club's liquidation process. ... Manchester United signed a four-year deal with 18-year-old Crewe midfielder Nick Powell. ... Manchester United will play AmaZulu July 18 and Ajax Cape Town July 21 in a two-game preseason trip to South Africa. ... The English Premier League announced the sale of domestic TV rights to BSkyB and BT for $4.69 billion in a record three-year deal. ... Chelsea interim coach Roberto Di Matteo, who replaced the fired Andre Villas-Boas for the final 11 weeks of the season and led the team to the FA Cup and Champions League titles, was given the job full time. ... Harry Redknapp is out as Tottenham coach, a surprising development considering Redknapp was up for the England job but wanted to finish out the season with Tottenham. ... Former Denmark international Michael Laudrup is the new coach of Swansea. ... Queens Park Rangers signed forward Andrew Johnson and defender Ryan Nelsen. ... Gennaro Gattuso, who played 13 seasons with AC Milan, signed a two-year contract with Swiss club FC Sion. ... Pescara will begin its Serie A season with a two-point deduction after authorities in Italy issued the first sentences in a match-fixing scandal. ... Hannover signed 22-year-old Japan defender Hiroki Sakai from defending J-League champion Kashiwa Reysol. ... Valladolid earned the final promotion spot into the Spanish league after winning a two-leg playoff. ... Corinthians won at Santos, 1-0, and Boca Juniors beat visiting Universidad de Chile, 2-0, in the first legs of their Copa Libertadores semifinals. The second legs will be played Wednesday (at Corinthians) and Thursday (in Chile). ... Iraq and Iran are counting on a couple of big-name coaches to get them to the 2014 World Cup. Iraq is coached by former Brazil midfielder Zico, while Iran is guided by Carlos Queiroz. ... Former Dutch international Wim Koevermans is the new coach of India. ... Brazil claims that more than $260 million in hospitality packages have already been sold for the 2014 World Cup, equaling the total revenue generated by the hospitality program for the 2010 tournament in South Africa. ... Europe's top clubs are set to get a 15 percent raise in Champions League prize money for the next three seasons. UEFA's current three-year Champions League broadcasting and sponsorship deals have earned $1.46 billion annually, and finalists typically earn around $66 million each. Increased demand and improved contracts will see combined revenues for the Champions League and Europa League top $2 billion for the 2012-15 cycle. ... Aston Villa midfielder Brett Holman was voted Player of the Year by his peers in Australia's professional footballers association. Striker Alex Brosque, who plays for Shimizu S-Pulse in Japan, was second, followed by Reading goalkeeper Adam Federici. ... Two former heads of China's football association, Xie Yalong and his successor, Nan Yong, were each sentenced to 10½ years in prison for taking bribes. The sentences were part of a sweeping crackdown on corruption in the sport. ... Diego Maradona's Al Wasl team banned goalkeeper Majed Naser for next season after he head-butted a player on the opposing team during a goal celebration during the GCC Champions League final. The club also said Maradona will return as coach next season but the club's entire board resigned. ... ... Alcides Ghiggia, who scored the goal that beat Brazil and won the 1950 World Cup for Uruguay, is in critical condition in a coma with multiple injuries and breathing problems following a traffic accident in Uruguay. Ghiggia is 85.
